cuberef.name: AssaultCube Reference
cuberef.description: This reference describes the commands and variables available in AssaultCube.

section.name: CubeScript
section.description: This section describes identifiers that are closely related to the CubeScript language.

command.description: Performs an addition.

remarks.remark: Example: echo the sum of x and y is (+ $x $y)

command.description: Performs a subtraction.
Performs a multiplication.

command.name: div
command.description: Performs a division.

command.name: mod
command.description: Performs a modulo operation.
Determines if two values are equal.
Determines if two values are not equal.
Determines if a value is smaller than a second value.
Determines if a value is bigger than a second value.
Determines if a values is less than or equal than a second value.
Determines if a values is greater than or equal than a second value.
logical AND.

example.explanation: Output: 1
Output: 0

command.description: logical OR.

example.explanation: output: 1
output: 0

command.name: rnd
command.description: Random value

argument.description: The upper limit of the random value

return.valueNotes: larger or equal 0 and smaller than A

command.name: strcmp
command.description: Determines if two strings are equal.

command.name: if
command.description: Controls the script flow based on a boolean expression.

example.code: if (> $x 10) [ echo x is bigger than 10 ] [ echo x too small ]

argument.description: the body to execute if the condition is true
the body to execute if the condition is true

command.name: loop
command.description: Loops the specified body.

remarks.remark: This command sets the alias you choose, as first argument, from 0 to N-1 for every iteration.

argument.description: the body to execute on each iteration

command.name: while
command.description: Loops the specified body while the condition evaluates to true.

remarks.remark: This command sets the alias "i" from 0 to N-1 for every iteration. Note that the condition here has to have [], otherwise it would only be evaluated once.

example.code: alias i 0; while [ (< $i 10) ] [ echo $i; alias i (+ $i 1) ]

argument.description: the body to execute on each iteration

command.name: concat
command.description: Concatenates multiple strings with spaces inbetween.

example.explanation: output: hello world

command.name: concatword
command.description: Concatenates multiple strings.

remarks.remark: The newly created string is saved to the alias 's'.

example.explanation: output: CubeScript

command.name: at
command.description: Grabs a word out of a string.

example.explanation: output: two

return.description: the word from the specified idex

command.name: findlist
command.description: Searches a list for a specified value.

return.description: the index of the item in the list

command.name: sleep
command.description: Executes a command after specified time period.

example.explanation: Prints 'foo' to the screen after 1 second.

variable.name: numargs
variable.description: The number of arguments passed to the current alias

variable.name: browsefiledesc
variable.description: Toggles getting descriptive text from CGZ or DMO files in menudirlist.

variable.name: physinterp
variable.description: Toggles physics interpolation.

command.name: menudirlist
command.description: create a menu listing of files from a path and perform an action on them when clicked.

remarks.remark: use this inside menu definitions, almost always as the only command of that menu.
compare the usage inside config/menus.cfg

example.explanation: will create a list of maps and load them when clicked

command.name: toggleconsole
command.description: Toggles the console.

command.name: jump
command.description: Triggers a jump.

remarks.remark: default keys: space and right mouse.

command.name: updatefrommaster
command.description: Contacts the masterserver and adds any new servers to the server list.

remarks.remark: The servers are written to the config/servers.cfg file. This menu can be reached through the Multiplayer menu.

command.name: millis
command.description: Returns the number of milliseconds since engine start.

command.name: systime
command.description: seconds since the epoch (00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970)

command.name: timestamp
command.description: a list of values for current time

remarks.remark: format: YYYY mm dd HH MM SS

command.name: datestring
command.description: representation of date

remarks.remark: format: Www Mmm dd hh:mm:ss yyyy
Use timestamp to create your own formatting.

command.name: timestring
command.description: the current time in (H)H:MM:SS format

command.name: bind
command.description: Binds a key to a command.

remarks.remark: To find out what key names and their default bindings are, look at config/keymap.cfg, then add bind commands to your autoexec.cfg.

command.name: onrelease
command.description: Executes a command on the release of a key/button.

remarks.remark: This command must be placed in an action in a bind or in an alias in a bind.

example.code: bind CTRL [ echo "key pressed"; onrelease [ echo "key released" ] ]

command.name: alias
command.description: Binds a name to commands.

example.code: alias myalias [ echo "hello world"; alias myalias [ echo "I already said hello" ] ]
example.explanation: It is possible to re-bind an alias, even during its evaluation.
There is also the shorthand version of defining an alias via the "="-sign.

command.name: quit
command.description: Quits the game without asking.

command.name: forward
command.description: Moves the player forward.

remarks.remark: default keys: W and Up Arrow

command.name: backward
command.description: Moves the player backward.

remarks.remark: default keys: S and Down Arrow

command.name: left
command.description: Moves the player left.

remarks.remark: default keys: A and Left Arrow

command.name: right
command.description: Moves the player right.

remarks.remark: default keys: D and Right Arrow

command.name: attack
command.description: Fires the current weapon.

remarks.remark: default: left mouse button

command.name: invmouse
command.description: Sets mouse to "flight sim" mode.

command.name: minmillis
command.description: Sets the minimum number of milliseconds a frame should take.

remarks.remark: This is for very fast machines that run Cube at hundreds of fps. Default is 5, i.e. try to stay close to 200fps. This command is not exact, i.e. the precise delay it generates depends on OS and other factors... experiment with your ideal setting.

command.name: screenshot
command.description: Takes a screenshot.

remarks.remark: Screenshots are saved to "screenshots/screenshotN.bmp", where N is the number of milliseconds since the game was launched.

command.name: exec
command.description: Executes all commands in a specified config file.

command.name: keymap
command.description: Sets up the keymap for the specified key.

remarks.remark: You should never have to use this command manually, use "bind" instead.

command.name: sensitivity
command.description: Sets the mouse sensitivity.

remarks.remark: With 'sensitivityscale' you can specify a number that the sensitivity is divided by.

command.name: addserver
command.description: Adds a server to the list of server to query in the server list menu.

argument.description: the address of the server (hostname or IP)

command.name: resetsecuremaps
command.description: Clears the list of secured maps.

command.name: securemap
command.description: Adds a map to the list of secured maps.

remarks.remark: Secured maps can not be overwritten by the commands sendmap and getmap.

variable.name: networkdebug
variable.description: Enables output of processed network packets.

remarks.remark: This variable only has an effect if the client binary is compiled in debug mode.

variable.name: autogetmap
variable.description: Determines if the current played map should be automatically downloaded if it is not available locally.

variable.name: clockerror
variable.description: Sets the correction value for clockfix.

remarks.remark: if(clockfix) millis = int(millis*(double(clockerror)/1000000));

variable.name: clockfix
variable.description: Enables correction of the system clock.

variable.name: dbgts
variable.description: Enable triangle debug.

remarks.remark: Prints details while connecting triangles of 3d models.

variable.name: maxfps
variable.description: Limits the FPS (frames per second) of the game.

variable.name: maxtmus
variable.description: Gets the maximum number of supported textures when performing multitexturing.

variable.name: minlod
variable.description: Minimal level of detail.

variable.name: modeacronyms
variable.description: Toggles use of acronyms instead of full modenames in the serverbrowser.

variable.name: resetbinds
variable.description: Resets all binds back to their default values.

remarks.remark: This command executes the file /config/resetbinds.cfg which will bind all keys to the values specified in that file, thus resetting the binds to their default values.

variable.name: changeteam
variable.description: Swaps your player to the enemy team.

variable.name: resetcfg
variable.description: Determines if all settings should be reset when the game quits.

remarks.remark: It is recommended to quit the game immediately after enabling this setting. Note that the reset happens only once as the value of this variable is reset as well.

variable.name: smoothdist
variable.description: Determines the valid distance when extrapolating a players position.

variable.name: smoothmove
variable.description: Determines the speed when extrapolating a players position.

variable.name: throttle_accel
variable.description: Determines how fast network throttling accelerates.

variable.name: throttle_decel
variable.description: Determines how fast network throttling decelerates.

variable.name: throttle_interval
variable.description: Determines the interval of re-evaluating network throttling.

variable.name: tsswap
variable.description: Swaps vertices of model triangles.

variable.name: version
variable.description: Gets an integer representing the game version. READ ONLY

remarks.remark: As example, version 1.0 is represented as value 1000.

variable.name: gamemode
variable.description: Holds the current game mode. READ ONLY

example.explanation: Output: 5

variable.name: connected
variable.description: Indicates if a connection to a server exists.

variable.name: maxroll
variable.description: Sets the maximum value the display will roll on strafing.

variable.name: rate
variable.description: Sets the clients maximum downstream bandwidth.

remarks.remark: Leaving it at 0 (the default) means the server will dynamically try to do the best thing, this is recommended for players who don't have a clue what their bandwidth is (setting your rate unoptimally is worse than not setting it all). Modem players (56k) could try rate 4000 and tweak from there, dsl players can try rate 6000-10000. Note that the more players on a server, the more critical the effect of your rate. If you are tweak addicted, you can try playing with the variables throttle_decel (how quickly to start dropping packets when your connection becomes bandwidth limited) throttle_accel (how quickly to recover once bandwidth becomes available again) and throttle_interval (how quickly to reestimate the situation). Change the defaults at your own risk.

section.name: Gameplay
section.description: This section describes gameplay related identifiers.

command.name: alive
command.description: Returns 1 if the local player is alive.

example.explanation: Output: 1

command.name: curmap
command.description: Returns the current map being played.

remarks.remark: If you pass it a non-zero value, the result will be path-less.

example.explanation: output: playing maps/ac_complex vote for: ac_complex

command.name: curmode
command.description: Returns the mode number for the current game.

command.name: curprimary
command.description: Returns the weapon-index the local player currently has selected as primary.

remarks.remark: This is not the same as curweapon - which could be a grenade or the knife.

command.name: currole
command.description: Returns 1 if the local player has admin privileges, 0 otherwise.

command.name: curserver
command.description: Returns information on the current server - if you're connected to one.

remarks.remark: If I is 0 (omitted or any other value than the ones below) you will get a string with 'HOST:PORT IP DESC'
If I is 1,2 or 3 you will get the IP, HostName or port respectively.
If I is 4 you get a string representing the current state of the peer - usually this should be 'connected'.

example.explanation: Output: I am connected to ctf-only.assault-servers.net
This will either remember or retrieve the last server you pressed the PrintScreen-key on.

command.name: curteam
command.description: Returns 1 if the local player is on the RVSF team, 0 if on CLA.

command.name: curweapon
command.description: Returns the weapon-index the local player is currently holding.

command.name: map
command.description: Loads up a map in the gamemode set previously by the 'mode' command.

remarks.remark: If connected to a multiplayer server, it votes to load the map (others will have to type "map M" as well to agree with loading this map). To vote for a map with a specific mode, set the mode before you issue the map command.

A map given as "blah" refers to "packages/maps/blah.cgz", "mypackage/blah" refers to "packages/mypackage/blah.cgz". At every map load, "config/default_map_settings.cfg" is loaded which sets up all texture definitions, etc. Everything defined there can be overridden per package or per map by creating a "mapname.cfg" which contains whatever you want to do differently from the default.

When the map finishes it will load the next map when one is defined, otherwise it reloads the current map. You can define what map follows a particular map by making an alias like (in the map script): alias nextmap_blah1 blah2 (loads "blah2" after "blah1").

argument.description: Name of the map to load

command.name: nextprimary
command.description: Returns the primary weapon on next respawn.

command.name: reload
command.description: Reloads the weapon.

command.name: skin
command.description: Determines the skin of the current player.

remarks.remark: See the player model folder for the according skin-id.

command.name: name
command.description: Sets the nick name for the local player.

command.name: say
command.description: Outputs text to other players.

remarks.remark: If the text begins with a percent character (%), only team mates will receive the message.

command.name: saycommand
command.description: Puts a prompt on screen.

remarks.remark: this puts a prompt on screen that you can type into, and will capture all keystrokes until you press return (or esc to cancel). If what you typed started with a "/", the rest of it will be executed as a command, otherwise its something you "say" to all players.

variableArgument.description: the text to display in the prompt

remarks.remark: The completion will work on the first word of your console input.

example.explanation: If you enter "/demo " and press TAB you will cycle through all available demos.
helper alias for quickly adding complete-definitions for all gamemodes - see config/script.cfg (below "Auto-Completions")

command.name: nickcomplete
command.description: adds a command to complete nicknames on

remarks.remark: your own nick will be ignored

example.explanation: with this you can enter "/nickgreet " and cycle via TAB to the nickname you want to greet.

command.name: connect
command.description: Connects to a server.

remarks.remark: If the server name ist omitted, the client will try to connect to an available server in the LAN. If the port is omitted or set to 0, the default port will be used.

argument.description: the address of the server (hostname or IP)

command.name: connectadmin
command.description: Connects to a server and tries to claim admin state.

remarks.remark: This command will connect to a server just like the command 'connect' and try to claim admin state. If the specified password is correct, the admin will be able to connect even if he is locked out by ban, private master mode or taken client slots. If successfully connected, bans assigned to the admin's host will be removed automatically. If all client slots are taken a random client will be kicked to let the admin in.
If the server name ist omitted, the client will try to connect to an available server in the LAN. If the port is omitted or set to 0, the default port will be used.

example.explanation: connect as admin on port 777 of localhost
will try to connect to a LAN server on the default port as admin with the given password of "myAdminPassword".

argument.description: the address of the server (hostname or IP)

command.name: disconnect
command.description: Leaves a server.

command.name: followmode
command.description: Choose the mode of following. Either "chase" [3rd person] or "embody" [1st person].

remarks.remark: Default to 1.

key.description: toggle between chase and embody followmode

command.name: team
command.description: Sets the team for the local player.

command.name: showscores
command.description: Shows or hides the scores.

command.name: weapon
command.description: Changes the weapon.

command.name: magcontent
command.description: Returns contents of current magazine.

remarks.remark: A knife will always return 1.
Weapons that aren't available will return -1.

example.code:
wnames = "Knife Pistol Shotgun Sub Sniper Assault Grenades" numtwo = [ if (< $arg1 10) [ result (concatword 0 $arg1) ] [ result $arg1 ] ] ammoinfo = [ loop w (listlen $wnames) [ mc = (magcontent $w) mr = (magreserve $w) mt = (+ $mr $mc) if (> $mt 0) [ echo (numtwo $mc) "/" (numtwo $mr) ":" (at $wnames $w) ] ] ]
Output: 01 / 01 : Knife 08 / 64 : Pistol 30 / 60 : Sub

command.name: magreserve
command.description: Returns contents of magazine reserve.

command.name: getmap
command.description: Retrieves the last map that was sent to the server using 'sendmap'.

command.name: spectate
command.description: Toggle into spectator mode - only possible when you're dead!

command.name: stopdemo
command.description: Stops any demo recording or playback.

command.name: watchingdemo
command.description: Returns 1 when the current game is being played from a demo, else 0.

example.code: echo I am (at [not now] (watchingdemo)) watching a demo. "so, are you?"

command.name: suicide
command.description: Kills your player. You will lose 1 frag point and gain 1 death point when using this command.

command.name: demo
command.description: Plays a recorded demo.

remarks.remark: Playback is interpolated for the player whose perspective you view.

command.name: demoplayer
command.description: Shifts the camera to another demo player

variable.name: xhairwpsel
variable.description: Determines if bot waypoints should be selected/placed using the crosshair or by the nearest location to your player.

value.description: Note: This is turned on by default.

variable.name: minutesremaining
variable.description: Returns the remaining minutes of the currently played game.

variable.name: paused
variable.description: Determines if the game should be paused.

variable.name: autoreload
variable.description: Indicates if the weapons should be reloaded automatically.

variable.name: scopefov
variable.description: Determines the FOV when scoping.

variable.name: showmap
variable.description: Determines if the mini-map should be shown on screen.

variable.name: showscoresondeath
variable.description: Determines if scores should be shown on death.

variable.name: footsteps
variable.description: Indicates if the footsteps sound should be played

variable.name: footstepalign
variable.description: Maximum time span between player animation and the playback of the footstep sound

remarks.remark: If the footstep sound would be played immediately when entering the radius of the other player, it would not be synchronous to the player model animation.

variable.name: demoplaybackspeed
variable.description: Sets the playback speed for a demo.

remarks.remark: To see the effect, the variable must be set before playing a demo.

variable.name: gamespeed
variable.description: Sets the gamespeed in percent.

remarks.remark: This does not work in multiplayer. For entertainment purposes only :)

command.name: edittoggle
command.description: switches between map edit mode and normal.

remarks.remark: In map edit mode you can select bits of the map by clicking or dragging your crosshair on the floor or ceiling (using the "attack" identifier, normally MOUSE1), then use the identifiers below to modify the selection. While in edit mode, physics and collision don't apply (noclip), and key repeat is ON. Note that if you fly outside the map, cube still renders the world as if you were standing on the floor directly below the camera.
Hotkey E

command.name: edittex
command.description: Changes the texture on current selection by browsing through a list of textures directly shown on the cubes.

remarks.remark: Default keys are the six keys above the cursor keys, which each 2 of them cycle one type (and numpad 7/4 for upper).

The way this works is slightly strange at first, but allows for very fast texture assignment. All textures are in 3 individual lists for each type (both wall kinds treated the same), and each time a texture is used, it is moved to the top of the list. So after a bit of editing, all your most frequently used textures will come first when pressing these keys, and the most recently used texture is set immediately when you press the forward key for the type. These lists are saved with the map. make a selection (including wall bits) and press these keys to get a feel for what they do.

argument.description: the direction you want to cycle the textures in

command.name: editheight
command.description: Changes the height of the current selection.

remarks.remark: Default keys are [ and ] for floor level, and o/p for ceiling.

argument.description: the delta value to move it in

command.name: solid
command.description: makes the current selection all solid (i.e. wall) or all non-solid.

remarks.remark: This operation retains floor/ceiling heights/textures while swapping between the two. Default keys f and g respectively.

command.name: equalize
command.description: Levels the floor/ceiling of the selection.

remarks.remark: default keys , and .

command.name: heightfield
command.description: Marks the current selection as a heightfield.

remarks.remark: marks the current selection as a heightfield, with T being floor or ceiling, as above. A surface marked as heightfield will use the vdelta values (see below) of its 4 corners to create a sloped surface. To mark a heightfield as normal again (ignoring vdelta values, set or not) use "solid 0". Default keys are h (floor) and i (ceiling).

Heightfields should be made the exact size that is needed, not more not less. The most important reason for this is that cube automatically generates "caps" (side-faces for heightfields) only on the borders of the heightfield. This also means if you have 2 independant heightfields accidentally touch eachother, you will not get correct caps. Also, a heightfield is slightly slower to render than a non-heightfield floor or ceiling. Last but not least, a heightfield should have all the same baseheight (i.e. the height determined by a normal editheight operation) to get correct results.

command.name: vdelta
command.description: changes the vdelta value of the current selection

remarks.remark: Note that unlike all other editing functions, this function doesn't affect a cube, but its top-left vertex (market by the dot in the editing cursor). So to edit a N * M heightfield, you will likely have to edit the vdelta of (N+1) * (M+1) cubes, i.e. you have to select 1 row and 1 column more in the opposite direction of the red dot to affect all the vertices of a heightfield of a given size (try it, it makes sense :)

A floor delta offsets vertices to beneath the level set by editheight (and a ceil delta to above). Delta offsets have a precision of a quarter of a unit, however you should use non-unitsize vertices only to touch other such vertices. Default keys are 8 and 9 to decrease/increase the vdelta.

command.name: corner
command.description: Makes the current selection into a "corner".

remarks.remark: Currently there is only one type of corner (a 45 degree one), only works on a single unit (cube) at a time. It can be positioned either next to 2 solid walls or in the middle of 2 higher floorlevels and 2 lower ones forming a diagonal (and similar with ceiling).

In both cases, the corner will orient itself automatically depending on its neighbours, behaviour with other configurations than the 2 above is unspecified. Since the latter configuration generates possibly 2 floor and 2 ceiling levels, up to 4 textures are used: for example for the 2 floors the higher one will of the cube itself, and the lower one of a neighbouring low cube. You can make bigger corners at once by issuing "corner" on grid aligned 2x2/4x4/8x8 selections, with equal size solid blocks next to them.

command.name: undo
command.description: Multi-level undo of any of the changes caused by editing operations

remarks.remark: hotkey u

command.name: undomegs
command.description: Sets the number of megabytes used for the undo buffer.

remarks.remark: undo's work for any size areas, so the amount of undo steps per megabyte is more for small areas than for big ones (a megabyte fits 280 undo steps on a 16x16 area, but only 4 steps on a 128x128 area).

command.name: copy
command.description: Copies the current selection into a buffer.

remarks.remark: hotkey c

command.name: paste
command.description: Pastes a previously copied selection.

remarks.remark: To paste a selection back requires a same size selection at the destination location. If it is not the same size the selection will be resized automatically prior to the paste operation (with the red dot as anchor), which is easier for large selections.
hotkey v

command.name: replace
command.description: Repeats the last texture edit thruout the map.

remarks.remark: The way it works is intuitive: simply edit any texture anywhere, then using "replace" will replace all textures thruout the map in the same way (taking into account wether it was a floor/wall/ceil/upper too). If the there was more than one "old" texture in your selection, the one nearest to the red dot is used. This operation can't be undone.

command.name: newent
command.description: Adds a new entity

remarks.remark: (x,y) is determined by the current selection (the red dot corner) and z by the camera height, of said type. Type is a string giving the type of entity, such as "light", and may optionally take values (depending on the entity).

argument.valueNotes: light, sound, clip, playerstart, pistol, ammobox, grenades, health, armour, akimbo, mapmodel, ladder, ctf-flag

command.name: newent light
command.description: Adds a new light entity

remarks.remark: if only argument R is specified, it is interpreted as brightness for white light.

argument.description: red colour component. see remarks below.

command.name: newent playerstart
command.description: Adds a new spawn spot.

remarks.remark: The yaw is taken from the current camera yaw.

command.name: newent ammobox
command.description: Adds a new ammo box item.

command.name: newent pistol
command.description: Adds a pistol magazine item.

command.name: newent grenades
command.description: Adds a new grenades item.

command.name: newent health
command.description: Adds a new health item.

command.name: newent armour
command.description: Adds a new armour item.

command.name: newent akimbo
command.description: Adds a new akimbo item.

command.name: newent mapmodel
command.description: Adds a map model to the map (i.e. a rendered md2/md3 model which you collide against but has no behaviour or movement)

remarks.remark: The mapmodel identifier is the desired map model which is defined by the 'mapmodel' command. The order in which the mapmodel is placed in the map config file defines the mapmodel indentifier. The map texture refers to a texture which is defined by the 'texture' command, if omitted the models default skin will be used. The 'mapmodel' and 'texture' commands are placed in the map config normally. Mapmodels are more expensive than normal map geometry, so do not use insane amounts of them to replace normal geometry.

command.name: newent ctf-flag
command.description: Adds a CTF flag entity.

remarks.remark: Note that this entity is only rendered as flag if the current game mode is CTF.

command.name: newent ladder
command.description: Adds a ladder entity.

remarks.remark: Note that this entity is used for physics only, to create a visual ladder you will need to add a mapmodel entity too.

command.name: newent sound
command.description: Adds a sound entity.

remarks.remark: Will play map-specific sound so long as the player is within the radius. However, only up to the max uses allowed for N (specified in the mapsound command) will play, even if the player is within the radius of more N sounds than the max. By default (size 0), the sound is a point source. Its volume is maximal at the entity's location, and tapers off to 0 at the radius. If size is specified, the volume is maximal within the specified size, and only starts tapering once outside this distance. Radius is always defined as distance from the entity's location, so a size greater than or equal to the radius will just make a sound that is always max volume within the radius, and off outside.

A sound entity can be either ambient or non-ambient. Ambient sounds have no specific direction, they are 'just there'. Non-ambient sounds however appear to come from a specific direction (stereo panning). If S is set to 0, the sound is a single point and will therefore be non-ambient. However if S is greater than 0, the sound will be ambient as it covers a specified area instead of being a single point.

command.name: newent clip
command.description: Adds a clip entity.

remarks.remark: Defines a clipping box against which the player will collide.

argument.description: X radius around the box center
Y radius around the box center

command.name: delent
command.description: Deletes the entity closest to the player

remarks.remark: hotkey x

command.name: entset
command.description: Edits the closest entity.

remarks.remark: Overwrites the closest entity with the specified values.

argument.valueNotes: light, sound, clip, playerstart, clips, ammobox, grenades, health, armour, akimbo, mapmodel, ladder, ctf-flag

command.name: entproperty
command.description: Changes property of the closest entity.

remarks.remark: For example 'entproperty 0 2' when executed near a lightsource would increase its radius by 2.

argument.description: amount by wich the property is increased

command.name: clearents
command.description: Deletes all entities of said type.

command.name: recalc
command.description: Recomputes all there is to recompute about a map, currently only lighting.

remarks.remark: hotkey R

command.name: savemap
command.description: Saves the current map.

remarks.remark: savemap makes a versioned backup (mapname_N.BAK) if a map by that name already exists. If the name argument is omitted, it is saved under the current map name.

Where you store a map depends on the complexity of what you are creating: if its a single map (maybe with its own .cfg) then the "base" package is the best place. If its multiple maps or a map with new media (textures etc.) its better to store it in its own package (a directory under "packages"), which makes distributing it less messy.

argument.description: file name of the map, see command 'map' for the naming scheme

command.name: newmap
command.description: Creates a new map.

remarks.remark: The new map has 2^S cubes. For S, 6 is small, 7 medium, 8 large.

argument.description: the size of the new map

command.name: mapenlarge
command.description: Enlarges the current map.

remarks.remark: This command will make the current map 1 power of two bigger. So a 6 size map (64x64 units) it will become a 7 map (128x128), with the old map in the middle (from 32-96) and the new areas solid.

command.name: mapmsg
command.description: Sets the map message, which will be displayed when the map loads.

remarks.remark: You will need to use quote marks around the message, otherwise it save the message correctly.
For example: /mapmsg "Map By Author"

command.name: waterlevel
command.description: Sets the global water level for the map.

remarks.remark: Every cube that has a lower floor than the water level will be rendered with a nice wavy water alpha texture. Water physics will be applied to any entity located below it.

Performance notes: water is rendered for a whole square encapsulating all visible water areas in the map (try flying above the map in edit mode to see how). So the most efficient water is a single body of water, or multiple water areas that are mostly not visible from eachother. Players can influence how accurate the water is rendered using the "watersubdiv" command (map config).

command.name: fullbright
command.description: Sets all light values to fullbright.

remarks.remark: Will be reset when you issue a 'recalc'. Only works in edit mode.

command.name: showmip
command.description: Toggles between showing what parts of the scenery are rendered.

remarks.remark: Shows what parts of the scenery are rendered using what size cubes, and outputs some statistics about it. This can give map editors hints as to what architecture to align, textures to change, etc.

command.name: toggleocull
command.description: Turns occlusion culling on and off.

remarks.remark: The reason one may want to turn it off is to get an overview of the map from above, without having all occluded bits stripped out.

command.name: slope
command.description: Makes a slope out of the current selection.

remarks.remark: The selection must be a heightfield before this command can be used. The steps specify the slope with the red vertex as left-top, i.e. "slope 1 2" will make a slope that increases just 1 step from left to right, and is slightly steeper from top to bottom. "slope -6 0" decreases steeply from left to right, and does not slope at all from top to bottom. Note that like the vdelta command, an increasing vdelta goes further away from the player, regardless of floor or ceiling.

command.name: arch
command.description: Makes an arch out of the current selection.

remarks.remark: The selection must be a heightfield before this command can be used. Will make the arch in the long direction, i.e when you have 6x2 cubes selected, the arch will span 7 vertices. Optionally, sidedelta specifies the delta to add to the outer rows of vertices in the other direction, i.e. give the impression of an arch that bends 2 ways (try "arch 2" on an selection of atleast 2 thick to see the effect). Not all arch sizes are necessarily available, see config/prefabs.cfg.

command.name: archvertex
command.description: Defines a vertex delta for a specific arch span prefab, used by the 'arch' command.

remarks.remark: See config/prefabs.cfg for an example on usage.

command.name: perlin
command.description: Generates a perlin noise landscape in the current selection.

remarks.remark: Keep the seed the same to create multiple perlin areas which fit with eachother, or use different numbers if to create alternative random generations.

argument.description: the scale, frequency of the features
cube size, how many cubes to generate a surface for at once (unused)

command.name: select
command.description: Selects the given area, as if dragged with the mouse.

remarks.remark: This command is useful for making complex geometry-generating scripts. The current dimensions of the selection (either created by the user or this command) are in the variables selx, sely, selxs and selys and can also be read/modified.
Coordinates are as follows: after a "newmap 6" the top-left corner (the one where the red dot points) are (8,8), the opposite corner is (56,56) (or (120,120) on a "newmap 7" etc.).

argument.description: the length along the X axis
the length along the Y axis

command.name: registersound
command.description: Registers a sound.

remarks.remark: This command returns the sound number, which is assigned from 0 onwards, and which can be used with "sound" command. If the sound was already registered, its existing index is returned. registersound does not actually load the sound, this is done on first play.
See for example config/sounds.cfg.

command.name: scalelights
command.description: Scales all lights in the map.

remarks.remark: This command is useful if a map is too dark or bright but you want to keep the light entities where they are.

variable.name: Map editing
variable.description: A variable indicating if the game is in editmode.

variable.name: flrceil
variable.description: A variable indicating if the player looks at the floor or at the ceiling.

variable.name: lightscale
variable.description: Used to finetune the "overbright lighting" rendering feature when enabled.

remarks.remark: After changing this value, a "recalc" is needed to see the differences.

section.name: Menus
section.description: This section describes identifiers related to the menu gui.

command.name: menuinit
command.description: Specifies commands to be executed when a menu opens.

remarks.remark: This command should be placed after newmenu.

argument.description: The code to execute on init

command.name: newmenu
command.description: Creates a new menu.

remarks.remark: All menu commands placed after newmenu (i.e. menuitem, menuitemcheckbox, etc) are added into the menu until another "newmenu" command is specified.

command.name: menuitem
command.description: Creates a new menuitem.

remarks.remark: Upon activating the menuitem, the associated command will be executed. (See config/menus.cfg for examples). If the command argument is omitted, then it will be set to the same value as the description. If -1 is specified instead of the command to execute, then no command is executed when activating the item. If the rollover option is used, the menuitem will execute that command when selecting (but not activating) the menuitem.
(Note: To activate the menu item, select it, and either: Click, press SPACE or press ENTER/Return).

argument.description: The command to execute on selection of the menuitem.
The command to execute upon rolling over the menuitem.

command.name: showmenu
command.description: Displays the specified menu.

remarks.remark: The menu allows the user to pick an item with the cursor keys. Upon pressing return, the associated action will be executed. Pressing ESC will cancel the menu.

argument.description: the name of a previously defined menu

command.name: closemenu
command.description: Closes the specified menu if it is open.

remarks.remark: If it is open multiple times in the stack only the topmost instance will be closed!

argument.description: the name of a previously defined menu

command.name: menumdl
command.description: Specifies a model to render while displaying the last added menu.

command.name: chmenumdl
command.description: Changes the menu model of a specified menu.

section.name: Head-Up Display
section.description: This section describes the identifiers to configure the head-up display (HUD).

command.name: clearminimap
command.description: Recreates the minimap for the current map.

command.name: history
command.description: Executes the specified command in the command line history.

remarks.remark: For example, binding "history 1" to a key allows you to quickly repeat the last command typed in (useful for placing many identical entities etc.)

argument.description: the N'th command from the history

command.name: conskip
command.description: Allows to browse through the console history by offsetting the console output.

variable.name: minimapres
variable.description: Sets the resolution for the minimap.

variable.name: hidestats
variable.description: Turns on/off display of fps/rendering stats on the HUD.

value.description: Turns the stats off (1) or on (0)

variable.name: crosshairsize
variable.description: Sets the size of your crosshair.

remarks.remark: The crosshair is turned off entirely if the size is set to 0.

variable.name: crosshairfx
variable.description: Turns on or off crosshair effects.

remarks.remark: When on, the crosshair will go grey when the weapon is reloading, orange when health is 50 or red when is 25.

value.description: Turns the effects on (1) or off (0)

section.name: Visuals
section.description: This section describes identifiers to configure the visuals.

variable.name: fov
variable.description: Sets the field of view (fov).

variable.name: gibnum
variable.description: Sets the number of gibs to display when performing a "messy" kill (grenade, knife, sniper headshot).

remarks.remark: Larger values are more spectacular, but can slow down less powerful machines. Reducing gibttl may help in this case.

variable.name: gibttl
variable.description: Sets the time for gibs to live (in milliseconds), after which they will disappear.

variable.name: gibspeed
variable.description: Sets the velocity at which gibs will fly from a victim.

variable.name: teamdisplaymode
variable.description: Sets the team display mode.

remarks.remark: In mode 0 team display is disabled In mode 1 players will be rendered with a colored vest to make the teams distinguishable. In mode 2 almost the whole suit of the players will be colored. These display modes are only applied in team gamemodes.

variable.name: aadynshadow
variable.description: Sets the size/resolution of the dynamic shadow data.

variable.name: dynshadowsize
variable.description: Sets the display size of the dynamic shadows.

variable.name: saveshadows
variable.description: Sets if dynamic shadows should be saved to disk.

variable.name: dynshadow
variable.description: Sets the alpha value (transparency) for dynamic shadows.

variable.name: dynlight
variable.description: Determines wether dynamic shadows and lights are rendered, providedjust incase they slow your fps down too much.

remarks.remark: With radius you can specify the radius of a dynamic light, smaller to maybe gain some speed (0 is off entirely), or bigger to see the effect of dynamic shadows more dramatically (try shooting it past some pillars that have a dark area on the other side... or use the "gamespeed" variable).

value.description: the radius of a dynamic light

variable.name: watersubdiv
variable.description: Determines the subdivision of the water surface in maps.

remarks.remark: Must be a power of 2: 4 is the default, 8 is recommended for people on slow machines, 2 is nice for fast machines, and 1 is quite OTT. See "waterlevel" (edit reference) on how to add water to your own levels.

variable.name: fullscreen
variable.description: Enables or disables fullscreen.

remarks.remark: Not supported on Windows and Mac.

variable.name: fsaa
variable.description: Sets the level of fullscreen antialiasing (FSAA).

variable.name: scr_w
variable.description: Sets the screen width.

variable.name: scr_h
variable.description: Sets the screen height.

variable.name: colorbits
variable.description: Sets the bits per pixel value.

variable.name: depthbits
variable.description: Sets the bits for the depth buffer.

variable.name: vsync
variable.description: Enables or disables vsync.

variable.name: gamma
variable.description: Sets the hardware gamma value.

remarks.remark: May not work if your card/driver doesn't support it.

variable.name: lighterror
variable.description: Allows to finetune the amount of "error" the mipmapper/stripifier allow themselves for changing lightlevels.

remarks.remark: If this variable is changed this during play, a "recalc" is needed to see the effect.

value.description: the error value, 1 being the best quality

variable.name: particlesize
variable.description: Scales all particles.

variable.name: animationinterpolationtime
variable.description: Sets the time available for interpolation between model animations.

value.description: the amount of milliseconds for the interpolation

section.name: Sound
section.description: This section describes all identifiers related to music and sound effects.

command.name: sound
command.description: Plays the specified sound.

remarks.remark: See config/sounds.cfg for default sounds, and use registersound to register your own. For example, sound 0 and sound (registersound "aard/jump") both play the standard jump sound.

command.name: mutesound
command.description: Mute a specific game sound.

argument.description: ID of the sound to mute

command.name: unmuteallsounds
command.description: Unmutes all previously muted sounds.

variable.name: mapsoundrefresh
variable.description: Specifies the interval for checking mapsounds.

remarks.remark: If set to value 0, the map sounds will be checked in every frame without any interval limitation.

variable.name: audiodebug
variable.description: Enables verbose output for debugging purposes.

variable.name: gainscale
variable.description: Each subsequent played sound's gain-value is scaled by this percentage.

remarks.remark: This lowers the gain of the sounds before they are mixed, this might be useful in cases when the mixer has problems with too high gain values.

variable.name: musicvol
variable.description: Sets the music volume.

variable.name: audio
variable.description: Enables or disables the audio subsystem in AC.

variable.name: soundchannels
variable.description: Sets the desired amount of allocated sound channels.

remarks.remark: AC will try to allocate that number of channels but it is not guaranteed to succeed.

variable.name: soundvol
variable.description: Sets the sound volume for all sounds.

section.name: Ingame Reference
section.description: This section describes all indentifiers related to the ingame documentation reference.

command.name: docsection
command.description: Adds a new section to the ingame documentation.

command.name: docident
command.description: Adds a new identifier documentation to the last added section.

remarks.remark: An identifier represents a command or variable. The new identifier
The name may countain spaces to create a "multipart" identifier documentation that can be used to describe a complex argument as a single pseudo identifier, look at the examples.

example.code: docident fov "Sets the field of view."
docident "newent light" "Adds a new light entitiy."

command.name: docargument
command.description: Adds a new argument documentation to the last added identifier.

remarks.remark: An argument represents either a command argument or a variable value.
The last argument of an identifier can be flagged as variable-length to indicate that it represents an unknown number of arguments.

command.name: docremark
command.description: Adds a new documentation remark to the last added identifier.

command.name: docexample
command.description: Adds an example to the last added identifier.

command.name: docref
command.description: Adds a new documentation reference to an identifier.

remarks.remark: The new reference is added to the last added identifier documentation.

command.name: docundone
command.description: Outputs a list of yet undocumented identifiers (commands,variables, etc)

remarks.remark: If the one argument is omitted, only the builtin identifiers will be listed. Therefore specify the argument other identifers like aliases should be included too.
Note that the list also includes identifiers that contain the substrings "TODO" or "UNDONE" in their documentation.

command.name: docinvalid
command.description: Outputs a list of identifer documentations that do not match any existing identifer.

remarks.remark: Multipart identifiers are not included in this list, see 'docident'.

command.name: docfind
command.description: Searches the ingame docs for identifier documentations matching the specified search string.

remarks.remark: The name, description and remarks are included in the search.

command.name: docwritebaseref
command.description: Writes out a base XML documentation reference containing templates for the builtin identifiers.

remarks.remark: The generated reference is written to "config/autogenerated_base_reference.xml" by default. The three arguments can be changed later on in the generated XML document.

section.name: Server commands
section.description: This section lists commands used by the client that communicate to the server. Most are used for server administration. Also see the "mode" section and the "map" command which also communicate to the server.

command.name: autoteam
command.description: Sets automated team assignment.

command.name: ban
command.description: Temporarally bans the specified player from the server.

remarks.remark: Temporary ban duration is fixed at 20 minutes.

command.name: callvote
command.description: Calls a vote on the server.

remarks.remark: This command is wrapped by aliases for better usability and is used to action votes such as ban, kick, etc. See config/admin.cfg for actual uses.

command.name: forceteam
command.description: Forces the specified player to join the enemy team.

argument.description: The player to assign to a team

command.name: giveadmin
command.description: Gives admin state to the specified player.

remarks.remark: Requires admin state. The admin will lose his admin state after successfully issuing this command.

command.name: kick
command.description: Kicks the specified player from the server.

command.name: mastermode
command.description: Sets the mastermode for the server.

remarks.remark: If the mastermode is set to 'private', no more clients can join the server. Default is 'open' which allows anyone to join the server.

command.name: removebans
command.description: Removes all temporary bans from the server. Temporary bans are normally automatically removed after 20 minutes.

command.name: sendmap
command.description: Sends the current map to the server and sends other players a message about it.

remarks.remark: If the map argument is specified, the map is first saved and then reloaded before sending it. Note: It's always required to be on the map one wants to send before issuing this command!

argument.description: Map to save and reload locally

command.name: setadmin
command.description: Claims or drops admin status.

remarks.remark: Successfully claiming admin status makes all other player votes invalid. Failed logins result in an auto kick. The admin is granted the right to kick, ban, remove bans, set autoteam, set shuffleteam, change server description (if enabled), change map, change mastermode, force team, change mode, record demos, stop demos and clear demo(s) - All without needing votes from other users. In the scoreboard, the admin will be shown as a red colour.

command.name: coop
command.description: Starts a map with the mode "Co-op edit"

remarks.remark: See the co-op edit section in page 4 of the map editing guide for more information.

variableArgument.description: The name of the map you wish to edit

command.name: ctf
command.description: Starts a map with the mode "Capture the Flag"

variableArgument.description: The name of the map you wish to play

command.name: dm
command.description: Starts a map with the mode "Deathmatch"

variableArgument.description: The name of the map you wish to play

command.name: htf
command.description: Starts a map with the mode "Hunt the Flag"

variableArgument.description: The name of the map you wish to play

command.name: ktf
command.description: Starts a map with the mode "Keep the Flag"

variableArgument.description: The name of the map you wish to play

command.name: lms
command.description: Starts a map with the mode "Last man standing"

variableArgument.description: The name of the map you wish to play

command.name: lss
command.description: Starts a map with the mode "Last swiss standing"

variableArgument.description: The name of the map you wish to play

command.name: mode
command.description: Sets the gameplay mode to N for the next map loaded.

remarks.remark: You will need to define mode before loading the map or it will stay as the last mode played.

command.name: osok
command.description: Starts a map with the mode "One shot, One kill"

variableArgument.description: The name of the map you wish to play

command.name: pf
command.description: Starts a map with the mode "Pistol frenzy"

variableArgument.description: The name of the map you wish to play

command.name: tdm
command.description: Starts a map with the mode "Team Deathmatch"

variableArgument.description: The name of the map you wish to play

command.name: tktf
command.description: Starts a map with the mode "Team keep the Flag"

variableArgument.description: The name of the map you wish to play

command.name: tosok
command.description: Starts a map with the mode "Team one shot, One kill"

variableArgument.description: The name of the map you wish to play

command.name: ts
command.description: Starts a map with the mode "Team survivor"

variableArgument.description: The name of the map you wish to play

command.name: vip
command.description: Starts a map with the mode "Hunt the Flag". Some players prefer the name "VIP" for this mode.

variableArgument.description: The name of the map you wish to play

section.name: Editing configs
section.description: All the below commands are used specifically in map configuration files. Some of these commands can also be used without the need of a map configuration file.

command.name: fog
command.description: Sets the fog distance.

remarks.remark: You can do this for tweaking the visual effect of the fog, or if you are on a slow machine, setting the fog to a low value can also be a very effective way to increase fps (if you are geometry limited). Try out different values on big maps / maps which give you low fps. It is also good for asthetic features of maps especially when combined with "fogcolour".

command.name: fogcolour
command.description: Sets the fog and clearing colour.

command.name: loadnotexture
command.description: Binds a texture to be used if a slot couldn't be loaded with a given textures path.

remarks.remark: Binds the texture indicated in the filename to the texture slot of any textures that aren't found. The path is given exactly as with the texture-command, if it is omitted (or can't be loaded) the default is used. The default is located in packages/misc/notexture.jpg (not in packages/textures - where custom ones must reside!)

example.code: loadnotexture "makke/black.jpg" // Any missing texture will show up black

argument.description: file name of the texture to bind

command.name: loadsky
command.description: Loads a skymap for a map.

remarks.remark: The available skymaps reside in packages/textures/skymaps/..
To select a skymap you need to use the full path from "packages/" but only up to the underscore "_" in the filename.

argument.description: path to the six skybox textures

command.name: mapmodel
command.description: Registers a mapmodel that can be placed in maps.

remarks.remark: A mapmodel registered with this command can be placed in a map using the 'newent mapmodel' command. The bounding box is an invisible force surrounding the model, allowing players to collide against it, instead of walking through the mapmodel. For more information about this command, read mapediting5.xml.
Example: mapmodel 4 2 4 0 "modelname"
This mapmodel has a bounding box of 8x8x2 in size (X/Y/Z) and by default hovers 4 units above ground.

argument.description: The square radius of the bounding box.
The height of the bounding box.
The initial height offset from the ground.
This integer is redundant. Leave it at zero so you don't break the command.
The name of the map model

command.name: mapmodelreset
command.description: Resets the mapmodel slots/indices to 0 for the subsequent "mapmodel" commands.

remarks.remark: Each subsequent mapmodel command increases it again. See config/default_map_settings.cfg for an example.

command.name: mapsound
command.description: Defines a mapsound.

remarks.remark: Registers the sound as a map-specific sound. These map-specific sounds may currently only be used with "sound" entities within a map. The first map sound registered in a map has slot/index number 0 and increases afterwards.

command.name: mapsoundreset
command.description: Resets the mapsound slots/indices to 0 for the subsequent "mapsound" commands.

remarks.remark: Each subsequent mapsound command increases it again. See config/default_map_settings.cfg for an example.

command.name: shadowyaw
command.description: Shadow yaw specifies the angle at which shadow stencils are drawn on a map.

remarks.remark: When specifying shadowyaw, remember that the default angle is 45 degrees. The example below would make the shadows appear at 90 degrees (45 degrees more to the left).

argument.description: The angle in degrees to rotate the stencil shadows

command.name: texture
command.description: Binds a texture to the current texture slot.

remarks.remark: Binds the texture indicated in the filename to the current texture slot and increments the slot number.

argument.description: This is a redundant value. Always leave this value as 0 here so it doesn't break your configurations.
File name of the texture to bind

command.name: texturereset
command.description: Sets the texture slots/indicies to 0 for the subsequent "texture" commands.

remarks.remark: Each subsequent texture command increases it again. See config/default_map_settings.cfg for an example.

command.name: watercolour
command.description: Determines the water colour in a map.

remarks.remark: You must define all 3 values, otherwise this command may not work correctly (use "1" as a placeholder if needed).
